S2.T1.caption: TABLE I: Comparison between different topics in Federated Learning
S2.T1.table:
Topic Strategy/Algorithm
Proximity FedProxÂ [17], SCAFFOLDÂ [18]
Quantization FedPAQÂ [19], ACGDÂ [20]
Secure FL NbAFLÂ [21], Privacy-Preserving FLÂ [22]
Blockchain-supported FLÂ [23]
Vehicular FL FVCÂ [24], FVNÂ [25]
Momentum FedMo [12], SlowMo [13], Mime [14]
references:
Federated Learning was first proposed in FedAvg [4]. It allows multiple clients to collaboratively train a global learned model without sharing their raw data. Apart from FedAvg, there are many algorithms/strategies that have been studied in FL (e.g., proximityÂ [17], quantizationÂ [19], differential privacyÂ [26], Vehicular FLÂ [25] etc.).
The idea of proximity is to apply an additional term on the basis of gradient descent by using the information of the global model to correct the local update. FedProxÂ [17] employs the proximal term to restrict
the local updates to be closer to the global model. SCAFFOLDÂ [18] employs the control variate to prevent â€œclient-driftâ€ [18]. The idea of the quantization technique is to reduce the size of transmission payload so as to reduce the communication overhead. FedPAQÂ [19] employs quantization operators on
the transmitted massages while ACGDÂ [20] employs gradient compression for communication. For Secure FL, NbAFLÂ [21] and [22] apply the Differential Privacy (DP)Â [26] in FL environment to protect the information leakage of the original raw data. In [23], authors proposes an adaptive framework consisting of blockchainÂ [27] and Reinforcement Learning (RL)Â [28] in FL to achieve higher trust and security. For Vehicular FL, FVCÂ [24] and FVNÂ [25] extend the traditional vehicular network [25] to the FL environment, where the vehicular network consists of groups of moving or stationary vehicles connected by a wireless network. However, these sub-topics are not the focus in this paper. We focus on momentumÂ [6]. The mainstream FL sub-topics are summarized in Table I.

S2.T2.caption: TABLE II: Comparison between different variants of momentum based federated learning algorithm
references: Momentum has been already well studied and proved to be more advantageous in centralized machine learning. In [9], authors study the utilization of momentum in over-parameterized models. [10] provides an unified convergence analysis for both Polyakâ€™s momentum and NAG. [11] studies NAG in stochastic settings. It also attracts researchersâ€™ attention to apply momentum in FL environment. FedMom [12] and SlowMo [13] perform momentum update in the aggregator only. In Mime [14], the aggregator computes the momentum and distributes it to the workers, which is then used by workers for local iterations. All these works also demonstrate the benefits of momentum in FL, but with more simplified approach compared with FedNAG. It is well-known that Nesterov Accelerated Gradient (NAG) [15] is a more advantageous form of momentum, but it is still not clear how to quantify the benefits of NAG in FL in the literature. This motives us to implement NAG in FL. In FedNAG, each worker computes its own momentum individually in each local iteration. The worker momenta will be also aggregated by the aggregator and re-distributed to workers. It brings substantial challenges in convergence analysis as well as better performance. This is a key issue to be addressed by this paper. A detailed comparison of different momentum-based FL algorithms is shown in TableÂ II. We also list important notations in TableÂ III.

references: Momentum has been already well studied and proved to be more advantageous in centralized machine learning. In [9], authors study the utilization of momentum in over-parameterized models. [10] provides an unified convergence analysis for both Polyakâ€™s momentum and NAG. [11] studies NAG in stochastic settings. It also attracts researchersâ€™ attention to apply momentum in FL environment. FedMom [12] and SlowMo [13] perform momentum update in the aggregator only. In Mime [14], the aggregator computes the momentum and distributes it to the workers, which is then used by workers for local iterations. All these works also demonstrate the benefits of momentum in FL, but with more simplified approach compared with FedNAG. It is well-known that Nesterov Accelerated Gradient (NAG) [15] is a more advantageous form of momentum, but it is still not clear how to quantify the benefits of NAG in FL in the literature. This motives us to implement NAG in FL. In FedNAG, each worker computes its own momentum individually in each local iteration. The worker momenta will be also aggregated by the aggregator and re-distributed to workers. It brings substantial challenges in convergence analysis as well as better performance. This is a key issue to be addressed by this paper. A detailed comparison of different momentum-based FL algorithms is shown in TableÂ II. We also list important notations in TableÂ III.

references: In this section we evaluate the convergence performance of FedNAG compared with benchmark algorithms including FedAvg, FedMom, centralized SGD (cSGD), and centralized NAG (cNAG) by real-world experiments. We then discuss the impacts of hyper-parameters, including global aggregation frequency

. Then, we explicitly generate different levels of non-i.i.d. data to test the performance of FedNAG and benchmarks. Finally, we perform trace-driven simulation as a digital representation of the mobile edge computing environment to analyze the total training time (including computation delay and communication delay).
